title: 113_hr3930
content: The "National Commission on the Structure of the Army Act of 2014" limits funds for reductions to the Army National Guard in terms of aircraft and personnel for fiscal year 2015. No funds can be used to divest, retire, or transfer any aircraft assigned to Army National Guard units as of January 15, 2014, or reduce personnel below authorized levels. The National Commission on the Structure of the Army is established with eight members appointed by various officials, as outlined in the Act. The National Commission on the Structure of the Army is established with appointments to be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Failure to make appointments by the specified date will result in a reduction of Commission members. The National Commission on the Structure of the Army is established with appointments to be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Appointment terms are for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed. Expertise in reserve forces policy is considered in appointments. Meetings are called by the Chair, and a majority of members constitute a quorum. The Commission shall select a Chair and Vice Chair from among its members, with a majority of members constituting a quorum for hearings. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with conducting a comprehensive study of the Army's structure to determine the optimal force mixture between the active and reserve components. Considerations include meeting current and future mission requirements, cost-efficiency balance, and leveraging unique strengths and capabilities. The Commission is focused on leveraging the unique strengths and capabilities of the Army's active and reserve components, ensuring capacity for homeland defense and disaster missions, maintaining trained personnel levels, and supporting operational tempo goals. The Commission will submit a report to the President and congressional defense committees by February 1, 2016, detailing its findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions based on the study conducted. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, use postal services, and accept gifts. Additionally, the Commission's personnel matters are outlined in Section 6. The Commission members who are not federal government officers or employees will be compensated at a daily rate equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule. Officers or employees of the United States serving on the Commission will not receive additional compensation. Members are also entitled to travel expenses at authorized rates while away from home. The Chair of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The compensation for these personnel can be determined by the Chair without adhering to specific regulations. The Chair of the Commission can appoint an executive director and staff with pay rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. The Commission will end 90 days after submitting its report. Funding for the Commission's activities can come from the fiscal year 2015 National Defense Authorization Act.
